title: Multiple Sclerosis: Sudden Hearing Loss and Brainstem Involvement
chief_complaint: I have been dealing with neurological issues for years, but about three weeks ago I developed constant ringing and a sudden loss of hearing in my right ear. I'm also having headaches and double vision again.

problem_summary.onset: Neurologic symptoms began 13 years ago; current auditory exacerbation began 3 weeks ago.
problem_summary.course: Waxing and waning neurologic course; sudden onset hearing loss in the right ear.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral neurologic involvement; Right ear sudden hearing loss; Left ear stable historical loss.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Constant tinnitus (right), intermittent headaches, episodic double vision (diplopia), vertigo, gait difficulty, ataxia, numbness (extremities, tongue), swallowing difficulties.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Inability to recognize speech in the right ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Diagnosis of sudden hearing loss etiology in the context of known neurologic history.

history.present_illness: Patient presents with a 3-week history of constant tinnitus and sudden hearing loss in the right ear, accompanied by headaches and diplopia. This occurs against a backdrop of a 13-year history of waxing and waning MS symptoms (numbness, gait issues, swallowing problems).
history.otologic_history: Previous history of left-sided, low-frequency hearing loss. Prior evaluation 10 years ago for suspected CPA tumor was negative.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis. History includes truncal paraesthesias, limb numbness, and swallowing difficulties.
history.prior_management: Evaluated by neurosurgeon 10 years prior; symptoms subsided for 3 years before current flare-up.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear shows mild low-frequency SNHL rising to normal. Right ear shows normal low-to-mid frequency thresholds with a precipitous drop to profound SNHL in the high frequencies starting at 3000 Hz.

numeric_results.RE_thresholds: 250-2000 Hz: ~10-20 dB HL; 3000 Hz+: Profound loss/No Response

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent recognition in the left ear. Right ear could not be assessed due to inability to recognize stimuli.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Abnormal bilaterally. LE: Normal Waves I & II, but poor definition of later waves; extended I-III interval; no obvious Wave V. RE: Only delayed Wave I evident; no Wave II.

numeric_results.RE_Wave_I: Delayed latency at 80 and 90 dB nHL

tests.name: MRI
tests.key_findings: Plaques in low pons and medulla, and periventricular regions. Lesions on both sides of low pons, greater involvement on the right side extending anterior-posterior.

overall_audiologic_summary: This 46-year-old female with a history of MS presents with sudden right-sided hearing loss. Audiometry reveals a precipitous high-frequency SNHL in the right ear and a stable, mild low-frequency SNHL in the left ear. Speech recognition is excellent in the left but absent in the right. ABR is grossly abnormal bilaterally, showing retrocochlear signs (delayed/absent waves, extended intervals) that correlate with MRI findings of demyelinating plaques in the lateral low pons, likely affecting the cochlear nuclei and proximal auditory nerve fibers.
counseling_points: Discuss the correlation between the sudden hearing loss and the MS flare-up (plaques in the brainstem).
Explain that the hearing loss in the right ear is sensorineural and currently affects speech understanding significantly.
Review ABR results indicating disruption in the neural pathways, consistent with the MRI findings.
Recommend continued management with neurology for the MS exacerbation.
Monitor hearing status, though recovery of the sudden loss may depend on the resolution of the acute MS plaque activity.
notes_for_actor: You have a long history (13 years) of strange neurological symptoms that come and go, so you are familiar with medical settings.
You are currently anxious because this is a 'sudden' loss in your 'good' ear (the right one), whereas your left ear has had mild issues for a long time.
You may exhibit slight physical signs of ataxia or unsteadiness if asked to walk.
You report 'constant' ringing in the right ear which is very bothersome.
